course.subject: IEDA
course.name: Statistics for Engineers
course.description: This is a systematic introduction to statistics for engineering, including descriptive statistics, point and interval estimation, hypothesis testing and linear regression analysis. In addition to theories, students will be taught a statistical language (R or Python) and have hands on experience of processing and analyzing data.
course.exclusions: IEDA 2510 (prior to 2018-19), MATH 2411, ISOM 2500, LIFS 3150

reviews.author: PyothePro
reviews.title: Introduction to Statistics
reviews.comment_content:
The content is actually quite simple. Most of the content should not be challenging for you if you had no issue with Math in High school.
1. Descriptive Statistics
2. Various Distributions
3. Random Sample
4. Point Estimation Methods
5. Interval Estimation Methods
6. Hypothesis Testing
7. ANOVA
8. Regression

Some of the proofs you will have to understand and memorize, but they're not too difficult.

The sad thing is that this course tells you interesting concepts, then tells you to take advanced courses for any deep detail.
reviews.comment_teaching:
Professor Wei You taught quite well. He would explain some tricky concepts/formulas in a way that anyone would be able to understand. In addition, he would normally reply to my questions via email in less than an hour, which is surprising considering the fact that he's probably a busy professor.
For the Tutorials, the TAs were okay. I get a good feeling that they could've prepared better for class, but it wasn't too bad.
The best part about the TAs is that they are very willing to help you out if you get stuck in the coding assignments.

Because I am a very lazy student, I didn't attend any real-time lectures and only watched zoom recordings since late March. (Sorry Prof)

reviews.author: Stpehen
reviews.title: A nice course with not-so-easy assignments
reviews.comment_content:
This is a standard introductory statistics course which covers the following:

- Descriptive statistics (Mean, IQR, box diagram...)
- Useful distributions (Normal, Binomial, Poisson, ...)
- Population and random sample (Estimators, Sample mean & variance, LLN & CLT, Properties of Normal Samples, Order statistics)
- Estimation of a parameter (MoM, MLE)
- Interval estimation (CI)
- Hypothesis testing (one-sample & two sample tests for normal (z, t, f), chi-squared test)
- ANOVA
- Linear regression

This course also have lab sessions which teach us how to use python to do statistic analysis. Although the course teach us using python to do statistic analysis, it is not needed in the midterm or final exam. You need to use it in your homework though.
reviews.comment_teaching:
The professor taught quite well and tried to explain the formulas step-by-step and gave us intuitive explanation for some concepts. He also response to my emails regarding the assignments attentively.

My one complaint would be the typos in the lecture slides. Some of the typos are not minor at all as some of them include formulas. If you didn't attend the lectures or didn't pay attention in the lecture, you might blindly follow the formulas when doing homework and get a wrong answer.

As for the lab sessions, I skipped most of them so I can't say much about it. All I know is I heard the TA didn't prepare quite well and was late.
reviews.comment_grading:
This semester is online so it might not be a good reference if you are taking this course face-to-face.

My score:
Homework (30%): 760/800
Midterm (30%): 60/60
Final (40%): ?/100
Grade: A

Midterm stat (from canvas):
Min: 10
Max: 60
Mean: 49.33

Final exam stat: not provided

There is a total of 8 homework, 1 of them is optional and doesn't count towards grades. 2 of them includes coding. The homework questions are not so easy compared to exam questions.

Getting full mark in midterm is not as incredible as you think(at least in my semester). Since the actual full mark of the paper is 70. There is one bonus question which weights 10 marks. As long as attempt to do it you should be able to get some bonus marks. Even if you get 70 marks your final score is still 60.

Both midterm and final exam are online proctored(in this semester) and open-book so you don't need to memorize the formulas. Midterm however, prohibits the use of calculator. This is tedious because you will need to calculate the confidence interval(CI) where you need to calculate the sample variance and sample mean of the data by hand. The question asking CI has more than 10 samples and each data is either a 3-digit number or 4-digit number, so this is where most of your exam time is going to be used on.
reviews.comment_workload:
The grading weight of homework and midterm are equal(both 30%) so it is NOT a good idea to be deadline fighter for the assignments.

From my personal experience, the first coding homework was surprisingly difficult which requires some coding knowledge such as for-loop and appending data into a list which is not explicitly taught in the lectures or lab sessions (meaning you can't copy-paste the code from lab notes and call it a day).
Make sure you start your assignments at least one day before the deadline in case you found difficulties in doing some questions. That way, you have time to ask the professor as well as give time for the professor to answer your questions.

For the exam preparation, doing the past paper provided and re-doing the homework problems should be fine. Since the exam is open-book, it is a good idea to print the lecture notes where it includes the key formulas such as formulas for CI and hypothesis testing.

Here is the description of the project:
Students are required to do a group project using statistical tools covered in this course.Each team will have at most 4 students. reviews.author: jacko
reviews.title: Bare-bones introductory statistics course
reviews.comment_content:
Topics covered in the course are point and interval estimation, hypothesis testing, regression analysis and a little bit of Bayesian statistics.

Unfortunately, the content isn't covered with great depth or mathematical rigor considering this is a course meant for engineering students. I'd recommend using other textbooks or youtube lectures to supplement your learning if you wanna build a good foundation.
reviews.comment_teaching: Only one lecture a week and no tutorial so I can't fault Prof Chen for not teaching very in depth. All lectures were recorded and the notes were pretty easy to follow which was quite nice.
reviews.comment_grading: Pretty good grading, getting an A is not hard. I can't remember the weighting but this course only has a midterm, final and weekly homework (which should count for about 10%). Basically the midterm and final were both around 5 problems (easy problems at that).
reviews.comment_workload: Weekly homework and that was about it. Homework was usually a mix of some problems on paper and simple coding problems (involving statistics). If you do the homework on your own then that basically counts as studying and you'll be ready for the midterm and final.

reviews.author: Tommy Li
reviews.title: Nice Course for Non-Math Students
reviews.comment_content:
This is a standard introductory statistics course which covers the following:

- Descriptive statistics (Mean, IQR, box fiagram...)
- Useful distributions (Normal, Binomial, Poisson, ...)
- Population and random sample (Estimators, Sample mean & variance, LLN & CLT, Properties of Normal Samples, Order statistics)
- Estimation of a parameter (MoM, MLE)
- Interval estimation (CI)
- Hypothesis testing (one-sample & two sample tests for normal (z, t, f), chi-squared test)
- ANOVA
- Linear regression

Unlike IEDA 2520, the content becomes more difficult. More in depth topic in probability and statistics are discussed. You will need to pay more attention in lectures in order to understand the content.

Compared to MATH 2411, this course discusses a wider range of content and in more depth. For example, chi-squared tests, multiple linear regression, methods for deriving estimators (MoM, MLE) are discussed. Moreover, this course adopts Python instead of R which I find really useful for my future machine learning studies.
reviews.comment_teaching:
Although the prof. seems that he would not be a good lecturer in the first one or two lectures. He proved himself teaching quite well when he started to move on to the more difficult topics. He tried to explain things clearly with nicely prepared slides. Sufficient illustrations and examples were provided to complement the teaching. For the topics that is more difficult, he would still leave us some insights (as a supplementary topic not examined or give references) instead of leaving them untied.

The professor was also quite responsible. He responded to emails and addressed issues promptly. Although I seldom ask him questions regarding to the lecture, he explained quite clearly for the question that I had in the assignment.
reviews.comment_grading:
Please refer to other reviews for judging the grading curve, my statistic is not that helpful. What I can say is, similar to IEDA 2520, the questions in the exam should be easier than the ones in MATH. The time given in exam is also not that strict so we do have some time to check answers. (except I failed to find a data entry error in 30 minutes (facepalm))

reviews.comment_workload:
This is a course with relatively high load considering the number of assignments given. There are a total 8 written + 6 coding assignments + a group project. Each of them takes a hour or two to complete so don't be a deadline fighter. The group project is self-proposed so try to propose one that interest you the most while being insightful.

For the exam preparation part, you may want to try some questions in the textbook. Only 1 past paper is given and it format is not similar due to the change in teaching mode. The exam would not be too difficult if you prepare well.
